周三，一场遥远的飓风引发的野火造成至少六人死亡，并摧毁了夏威夷毛伊岛的大部分地区，迫使数千人撤离，一些人逃入大海躲避烟雾和火焰。

多个社区被烧毁，包括旅游胜地拉海纳在内的岛屿西侧几乎与外界隔绝，只有一条高速公路开放，官员们表示，破坏范围广泛，但目前尚无法量化。

“我们刚刚经历了我见过的最严重的灾难。整个拉海纳都被烧成了灰烬。这就像一场世界末日，”逃离城市的拉海纳居民梅森·贾维说。

贾维向路透社展示了他拍摄的拉海纳海滨灰白色破坏的照片。他穿着短裤，大腿上还出现了水泡，他说这是他骑着电动自行车穿过火焰救狗时受的伤。

由于消防队员仍在与三场大火作斗争，毛伊岛西部除了紧急救援人员和疏散人员外对所有人关闭。

夏威夷交通部的埃德·斯尼芬 (Ed Sniffen) 表示，至少 4,000 名游客仍在试图离开毛伊岛西部。斯尼芬说，尽管至少有 16 条道路被关闭，但毛伊岛机场仍在全面运营，航空公司正在降低票价并提供豁免，以让人们离开该岛。

惊慌失措的撤离人员在社交媒体上发布了图片，显示曾经田园诗般的海滩和棕榈树上空滚滚浓烟。

达斯汀·约翰逊（Dustin Johnson）在拉海纳港为一家公司工作，他说：“当大火席卷榕树时，我是最后一个离开码头的人，带走了一切。我就跑出去，帮助沿途我能帮助的每个人。”提供两小时旅游的包船公司。他是在卡胡卢伊机场发表讲话的，该机场通常位于拉海纳以东 25 分钟车程处。

据毛伊县新闻稿称，一些人被迫跳入太平洋以躲避烟雾和火灾，促使美国海岸警卫队对他们进行营救。

官员们表示，他们正在调查有关人们被困在车里的目击者报告。

毛伊县市长理查德·比森在新闻发布会上说：“我们现在的主要重点是拯救生命，防止人类痛苦，并减少巨大的财产损失。”

比森对死亡人数知之甚少，称他是在简报会开始前才得知死亡人数。

国民警卫队少将肯尼思·哈拉（Kenneth Hara）表示：“一切都是流动的、动态的。就在我们说话的时候，他们正在进行搜救。”他敦促游客离开毛伊岛，并补充说他们可以在欧胡岛檀香山的一个会议中心寻求庇护。

副州长西尔维娅·卢克表示，由于停电和手机服务中断，疏散工作变得更加复杂，因为与毛伊岛西侧的通信只能通过卫星进行。

“我们的庇护所已经人满为患。我们的资源正在被征税，”卢克说。她补充说，该州已经开放了至少五个疏散避难所。

夏威夷的情况让人回想起今年夏天世界其他地方的灾难场景， 创纪录的高温引发的野火迫使希腊、西班牙、葡萄牙和欧洲其他地区数万人撤离，加拿大西部也遭受了不同寻常的打击。严重火灾。

科学家表示，由化石燃料使用驱动的人为气候变化正在增加此类极端天气事件的频率和强度，他们长期以来一直警告政府官员必须削减排放以防止气候灾难。

白宫发布了总统乔·拜登的唁电，他赞扬了消防员的工作，并下令“岛上所有可用的联邦资源帮助应对。”

拜登说，除了夏威夷国民警卫队外，美国海岸警卫队和海军第三舰队正在协助毛伊岛的搜救工作，美国海军陆战队正在向大岛派遣直升机，而美国交通部则协助疏散工作。

毛伊岛的起火原因尚未确定，但国家气象局表示，干燥的植被、强风和低湿度共同加剧了火灾。据夏威夷大学称，夏威夷群岛的某些地区几乎每年都会发生大火，尽管这些火灾的范围并不寻常。

根据卢克发布的紧急公告，截至周二晚上，夏威夷和毛伊县部分地区已有数百英亩土地被烧毁，道路和学校已关闭。夏威夷县包括位于毛伊岛南部的大岛。

官员们表示，多拉飓风带来的狂风助长了全州的火势。国家飓风中心表示，截至当地时间上午 11 点（格林尼治标准时间 2100），风暴位于檀香山西南约 860 英里（1,380 公里）处。

檀香山国家气象局预报员伊恩·马丁表示，最严重的强风应该会在周三晚些时候或周四早些时候结束。

  • 指责法国破坏尼日尔稳定

尼日尔军政府周三会见了两名尼日利亚特使，为在与地区领导人举行峰会之前进行对话带来了希望，峰会可能导致采取军事行动恢复民主。

此次会谈是在尼日尔指责法国侵犯其领空、袭击军营并释放“恐怖分子”以破坏该国之际进行的。巴黎否认了这些指控。

代表政变领导人发言的陆军军官阿马杜·阿卜杜拉马内在没有提供证据的情况下在视频声明中提出了这些指控，这在周四西非国家元首会议之前引发了紧张局势，预计会议将讨论包括对军政府采取军事行动在内的选项。

阿卜杜拉马内说：“我们看到的是一个破坏我们国家稳定的计划。”

法国外交部否认了这些指控，称法国飞机是根据与尼日尔军队达成的现有协议执行任务的，法国军队是应合法当局的要求进入这个西非国家的。

在对峙期间，军政府拒绝了非洲、美国和联合国特使的外交提议。尼日利亚政府消息人士称，军政府领导人周三破例在首都尼亚美会见了尼日利亚总统博拉·蒂努布的两名特使，博拉·蒂努布也是西非国家经济共同体（西非经共体）主席。

尽管边境关闭，这两位特使——著名的传统领导人拉米多·穆罕默德·萨努西和阿卜杜勒萨拉米·阿布巴卡尔——仍被允许进入该国。

只有萨努西会见了军政府领导人阿卜杜拉哈曼·蒂亚尼将军，而他的同行则在机场会见了其他代表。

“我们将继续尽最大努力让两党走到一起，增进了解。现在是公共外交的时候了，”萨努西返回阿布贾后告诉记者。

“残酷”拘留

尼日尔被废黜的总统穆罕默德·巴祖姆所在的政党指责7月26日掌权的军政府将他和他的家人“残忍”和“不人道”地关押在总统官邸。

周三，PNDS-Tarayya 党在一份呼吁全国动员起来拯救他们的声明中表示，巴祖姆一家没有自来水、没有电，也无法获得新鲜物品或医生。

美国国务院发言人马修·米勒表示，美国非常担心巴祖姆的安全，并仍在寻求推翻军事接管。

“我们继续与该地区的合作伙伴接触。我们继续与其他政府接触，”他在简报中说。

美国军队与法国、意大利和德国军队一起驻扎在尼日尔，这是国际社会根据与现已被废黜的文职政府达成的协议，打击破坏萨赫勒地区的伊斯兰叛乱分子的努力的一部分。

过去两年，反对前殖民国家法国的言论一直是该地区政变的一个特点，包括马里和布基纳法索，这两个国家的军队统治者强烈支持现在在尼亚美掌权的将军。

军政府已撤销与法国的军事协定，但巴黎拒绝了这一决定，称这不是尼日尔合法当局做出的。

内部挑战

政变是由国内政治引发的，但却演变成一场国际戏剧。西非经共体、联合国和西方国家已向军政府施压，要求其下台，而马里和布基纳法索则誓言捍卫军政府。

周三，政治局势变得更加复杂，前叛军瑞萨·阿格·布拉宣布成立新的共和国抵抗委员会（CRR），旨在恢复巴祖姆的权力。

阿格·布拉的声明称：“尼日尔是负责保护尼日尔的人们精心策划的悲剧的受害者。”他说，CRR 将使用“任何必要手段”来阻止军事接管并支持国际外交。

阿·布拉的挑战引发了尼日尔内部冲突的担忧，在政变之前，尼日尔一直是西方国家在该地区的重要盟友，而该地区其他国家已转向俄罗斯。

西方列强担心，如果尼日尔军政府效仿马里的做法，驱逐西方军队并邀请俄罗斯瓦格纳集团的雇佣兵，俄罗斯的影响力可能会变得更强。

阿格·布拉在 20 世纪 90 年代和 2000 年代尼日尔北部沙漠游牧民族图阿雷格人的起义中发挥了领导作用。与许多前叛乱分子一样，他被纳入巴祖姆及其前任穆罕默德杜·伊素福领导的政府。

政变导致边境和空域关闭，导致供应中断并阻碍了援助。此次收购还促使外国对世界上最贫穷的国家之一实施金融制裁。

金融市场专栏作家杰米·麦克吉弗 (Jamie McGeever) 对亚洲市场未来一天的展望。

对中国陷入通货紧缩的持续担忧以及美国通胀数据之前的谨慎态度将使周四市场受到控制，因为投资者还关注印度的利率决定、日本的批发通胀和菲律宾的GDP数据。

美国和中国之间重新出现的紧张局势可能会重新引起投资者的关注，白宫详细介绍了禁止美国对中国技术进行某些投资的计划，并要求政府就其他投资进行通报。

尽管中国股市周三连续第三天下跌，但亚洲其他地区并未受到中国通货紧缩数据的影响，MSCI 亚洲（日本除外）指数上涨 0.5%，创下本月迄今为止的最佳表现。

也许让人松了一口气的是，-0.3%的年通缩率并不像经济学家预期的-0.4%那么严重——这肯定足以将中国的经济意外指数提升至6月26日以来的最高水平。

同样，周四对美国通胀的解读比市场普遍预期更为温和，可能会缓解自惠誉于 8 月 1 日取消美国 3A 信用评级以来市场笼罩的阴霾。

周三标准普尔 500 指数在七个交易日中第六个交易日下跌，华尔街可能会稍稍松一口气，7 月份通胀报告预计将显示消费者价格年增长率从 3.0% 升至 3.3%。

不过，请密切关注油价。原油期货价格创下 1 月份以来的最高水平，目前仅比一年前下跌 9%，这与 6 月份 40% 的同比跌幅相比，通缩冲动明显减弱。

同样在通胀方面，日本批发价格通胀年率预计将从 6 月份的 4.1% 降至 7 月份的 3.5%。这将是 2021 年 3 月以来的最低水平，也是自 12 月 10.2% 的峰值以来连续第七次下降。

与此同时，印度储备银行周四预计将回购利率稳定在 6.50%，但面对近期食品价格上涨，其语气将更加强硬，此次上涨幅度超出预期，且持续时间预计更长。

利率市场预计加息四分之一个百分点的可能性很大，如果不是本周，那么肯定会在年底前加息。货币交易员似乎并没有预期会加息—— 卢比兑美元汇率在 10 月份的历史低点约 83 卢比兑美元汇率上行。

以下是周四可能为市场提供更多方向的关键进展：

- 印度利率决定

- 日本批发物价通胀（7 月）

- 菲律宾 GDP（第二季度）

周三，好莱坞编剧罢工一百天，合同谈判陷入僵局，纠察线上的人们抗议他们所说的无视他们的要求。

罢工于 5 月 2 日开始，此前美国作家协会 (WGA) 与主要制片厂之间的谈判在赔偿、编剧室最低人员配备以及流媒体时代的剩余付款等问题上陷入僵局。

作家们还试图规范人工智能的使用，他们担心人工智能可能会取代他们的创作投入。

娱乐行业高管一直在努力应对电视收入下降、电影票房尚未恢复到新冠疫情前水平以及流媒体业务基本上难以盈利的矛盾。

华纳兄弟探索公司 (WBD.O)首席执行官戴维·扎斯拉夫 (David Zaslav) 上周对投资者表示：“我们正处于未知领域。”该公司警告称，好莱坞劳工骚乱的不确定性可能会影响该公司的电影上映时间及其能力。制作和交付内容。

以美国演员工会 (SAG) 为代表的演员于 7 月 14 日就片酬和人工智能问题举行了罢工，有效地停止了有剧本的电视节目和电影的制作，并影响了整个娱乐界的业务。这是自 1960 年以来两个工会首次举行罢工。

上周召开的会议讨论了 WGA 与电影电视制片人联盟 (AMPTP) 之间恢复谈判的问题，该组织代表主要制片厂参与谈判，但没有确定返回谈判桌的具体日期。

当天晚些时候，WGA 向其 11,500 名成员发送了一条信息，抱怨机密会议中泄露的细节，但坚称该协会的谈判委员会“仍然愿意与公司接触并真诚地恢复谈判”。

WGA 没有回应对此报道的置评请求，AMPTP 也拒绝置评。

团结“震撼”

罗比·罗伯逊 (Robbie Robertson) 是加拿大裔美国乐队 The Band 的吉他手兼主要作曲家，以《The Weight》和《The Night They Drove Old Dixie Down》等歌曲而闻名，其经纪人周三表示，罗比·罗伯逊去世，享年 80 岁。

与罗伯逊共事 34 年的经纪人贾里德·莱文 (Jared Levine) 在一份声明中表示，罗伯逊 16 岁时离开多伦多的家去追求自己的摇滚梦想，周三在长期患病后于洛杉矶去世。

声明补充说：“罗比去世时，他的家人围绕在他身边。”

该乐队包括四名加拿大人——罗伯逊、里克·丹科、加思·哈德森和理查德·曼努埃尔——并由阿肯色州鼓手莱文·赫尔姆担任主唱。 The Hawks 最初被称为摇滚狂人 Ronnie Hawkins 的伴奏乐队，后来因支持鲍勃·迪伦 (Bob Dylan) 1965-1966 年的“Going Electric”巡演而受到关注。

在更名为 The Band 并在纽约伍德斯托克重新立足后，他们成为摇滚界最受尊敬的乐队之一。他们 1976 年在旧金山举行的告别音乐会是马丁·斯科塞斯 1978 年电影《最后的华尔兹》的基础。

乐队有一种独特的化学反应。他们以和声而闻名，Helm 拥有三位出色的歌手，贝斯手 Danko 和钢琴家 Manuel。管风琴演奏家和多乐器演奏家加思·哈德森（Garth Hudson）也至关重要。

“他们是货色，”罗伯逊在 2016 年的自传《证词》中这样评价他的四位乐队成员。 “这支乐队是一支真正的乐队。这里的钢丝没有丝毫松弛。每个人都竭尽全力地坚持自己的目标。”

“乐队首张专辑的影响力怎么夸大都不过分，”评论家格雷尔·马库斯 (Greil Marcus) 在 2000 年提到他们 1968 年的首张专辑《Music from Big Pink》时写道。其中包括《The Weight》和迪伦的《I Shall Be Release》等。

他们 1969 年的第二张专辑，标题为“The Band”，甚至更好。凭借他们的边疆风格和民谣、摇滚、乡村、灵魂和福音的独特融合，乐队影响了埃里克·克莱普顿 (Eric Clapton)、埃尔顿·约翰 (Elton John)、感恩而死乐队 (The Grateful Dead)、披头士乐队 (The Beatles) 等后来的音乐家，他们演奏的音乐在当时被称为“美国风格。”

他们的音乐让人回想起早期的美国，反映在诸如“Across the Great Divide”、“King Harvest (Has Surely Come)”、“Up on Cripple Creek”和“The WS Walcott Medicine Show”等歌曲标题中。

本土根源

Jaime Royal Robertson 于 1943 年 7 月 5 日出生于多伦多。他的母亲 Rosemarie Dolly Chrysler 是莫霍克和卡尤加血统的加拿大原住民。她嫁给了一位名叫吉姆·罗伯逊的加拿大陆军士兵。罗比·罗伯逊后来得知，他的亲生父亲是一位犹太血统的“赌牌老手”，名叫亚历克斯·克莱格曼，在罗比·罗伯逊出生前，他在一场高速公路肇事逃逸事故中丧生。

小时候，罗伯逊对安大略省西南部六国印第安人保护区的亲戚的拜访印象深刻。 2017 年，他在加拿大广播公司的“Metro Morning”节目中表示，“那里的每个人都可以演奏、唱歌、跳舞或用音乐做一些事情”，这让他感到震惊。“看到有人坐在你旁边的椅子上，听到他们的手指在桌子上移动。 instrument, and hear them breathing when they were singing, all of that, it gave me chills."

Robertson became infatuated with the guitar early on and gained a reputation as a guitar hot shot during his time with the Hawks. "Rolling Stone" magazine eventually ranked him No. 59 on its 2015 list of "100 Greatest Guitarists." His unique guitar style was displayed to great effect on such Band songs as "Jawbone" and "Smoke Signal."

After soaring to the highest heights on their first two albums, The Band continued to produce good work in the 1970s but a certain lethargy and lack of direction set in, not helped by the substance abuse problems of Danko, Helm and Manuel. They decided to pack it in by holding a star-studded concert in 1976 with such guests as Dylan, Clapton, Joni Mitchell, Neil Young, Van Morrison and Muddy Waters.

After The Band's breakup, Robertson created soundtracks for Scorsese films, including "Raging Bull." He made a foray into acting in 1980 with the film "Carny," starring Jodie Foster. He released several solo albums, exploring new sonic territory rather than trying to recapture the distinctive sound of The Band.

DARK TIMES

In the 1990s, acrimony emerged when Helm accused Robertson of failing to give co-credits to the other members on songs he claimed they had co-written. Robertson denied he had unfairly withheld credit.

Helm painted a scathing picture of Robertson in his 1993 autobiography. Robertson reacted more in sorrow than anger, often saying in interviews that Helm, in the early days, was "the closest thing I had to a brother."

The Band's members reunited in various configurations in the 1980s and 1990s and even made a few albums under The Band name, but Robertson never took part.

After The Band's breakup, a lifetime of hard living took its toll on the members. Manuel hanged himself in a Florida hotel room at age 42 in 1986. Danko died at age 55 in 1999. Helm died of throat cancer in 2012. Hudson is the remaining member still alive.

In February 2022, "Variety" reported, citing sources, that Robertson sold his music publishing catalog to a firm called Iconoclast for about $25 million.

After all the highs and lows, Robertson looked back at his Band mates with love and affection. "Through all the turbulence, I am left with such a deep appreciation for my journey," he wrote in his autobiography. "This shining path I've traveled being part of the Band - there will never be another like it. Such a gift, such talent, such pain, such madness ... I wouldn't trade it for anything."

The US special counsel investigating Donald Trump obtained a search warrant for the former president's Twitter account in January and the company delayed complying, according to a US appeals court opinion on Wednesday.

The US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit affirmed the federal trial judge's decision to hold Twitter, now known as X, in contempt and fine it $350,000.

The ruling said that Twitter had raised First Amendment concerns about a nondisclosure order issued over the warrant, as the company wanted to notify Trump about it.

"Under the circumstances, the court did not abuse its discretion when it ultimately held Twitter in contempt and imposed a $350,000 sanction," the ruling said.

Trump, in a post on his social media site Truth Social, said the Justice Department "secretly attacked my Twitter account, making it a point not to let me know about this major 'hit' on my civil rights." Prosecutors will often ask judges that targets of subpoenas issued in criminal probes not be notified in order to protect their investigations, a practice the appeals court cited in Wednesday's ruling.

A spokesperson for Smith declined comment and a spokesperson for X did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Wednesday's opinion did not identify which judge held Twitter in contempt.

While Trump's tweets are publicly viewable, the company also holds non-public information on accounts like direct messages, drafts of tweets, location data and the type of device used to send tweets.

The opinion said the warrant was related to Smith's investigation into the events surrounding the Jan. 6, 2021, siege on the US Capitol by supporters of Trump while he was still president.

Republican Trump last week pleaded not guilty to an indictment that charged him with plotting to overturn his November 2020 election loss to Democrat Joe Biden.

Trump is the front-runner for the Republican 2024 presidential nomination.

A Kremlin official involved in what international prosecutors call the illegal deportation of Ukrainian children to Russia was associated online as a teenager with white supremacist and neo-Nazi movements, Reuters has found.

The material posted online by Alexei Petrov between 2011 and 2014 remained on his social media account until late July this year when, following questions posed by Reuters, he deleted some videos, unsubscribed from two far-right online groups, and made one of his accounts private.

Petrov is a 27-year-old advisor in the office of Maria Lvova-Belova, Russia's presidential commissioner for children's rights. In March, the International Criminal Court issued arrest warrants for Lvova-Belova, along with Russian President Vladimir Putin, on charges of committing a war crime by forcibly deporting hundreds of children from Ukraine and taking them to Russia.

Lvova-Belova has denied committing any war crime. She has said vulnerable children were taken to Russia to shelter them from violence and protect them from a leadership in Ukraine that she has described as "Fascists" who have allowed "the virus of Nazism" to make a comeback.

Reuters found that when Petrov was aged between 16 and 19 he made at least three posts on social media containing videos, images or messages from a far-right organization that originated in Russia and promotes white racial supremacy, as well as three images and slogans associated with neo-Nazism.

Petrov's Skype handle incorporates the name of the white supremacist organization, Wotanjugend, and his Instagram handle contains a coded reference to Adolf Hitler widely used in far-right circles.

He had not changed his Skype handle as of July 31 this year. His Instagram account was disabled but Reuters was able to discern the handle because Petrov linked to it from his account on the VKontakte social media app. He deleted that link the day Reuters submitted its questions about his online activity to his employer.

A London-based private intelligence service called Molfar disclosed publicly in a Jan. 3, 2023 report about Russia's removal of children from Ukraine that Petrov's Skype handle is wotan_jugend8989. His other online associations to far-right and white supremacist movements have not previously been reported.

While Petrov posted content from or related to white supremacist and far-right groups, in none of the posts seen by Reuters did Petrov explicitly endorse them.

In a statement responding to Reuters questions, Petrov said: "Unequivocally, I never had, nor do I have, any links to neo-Nazi organisations. I have never been a member of, and did not have social network accounts linked to or relating to, Nazi organisations." He said it was impossible for him to remember what he reposted years ago, and since then groups on social networks could have changed their names, their activities, and their orientation. He did not specifically address any of the online posts or account handles that Reuters found.

The office of Russia's presidential commissioner for children's rights did not respond to Reuters questions. A Kremlin spokesman also did not respond.

A Dec. 16, 2022 European Union decision imposing sanctions on Petrov said he is "involved in the illegal transportation of Ukrainian children to Russia and their adoption by Russian families."

Petrov did not reply to Reuters' questions about the sanctions. He said in his statement he was helping children in need.

When Russia gave a presentation on April 5 this year to the United Nations Security Council to rebut allegations about its treatment of Ukrainian children, Petrov was among the speakers.

In a video shared during that presentation, Petrov was shown alongside children at a Russian-organised camp for Ukrainian children. He said in the video the aim of the camps is that: "through friendly communication, the kids will find their childhood dreams which will in the future become a reality for them."

His employer, which organizes the camps, say they prepare youngsters for life in Russia. Ukraine says they strip children of their national identity by making them sing the Russian national anthem and learn Russian history, as well as teaching them classes on Russian patriotism.

Reuters couldn't independently establish the activities at the camps nor Petrov's precise role in them.

NEO-NAZI SYMBOLS

Reuters was able to link the Skype account wotan_jugend8989 to Petrov because he used an email address associated with him to set it up. Reuters also found around a dozen online forums - from soccer fan sites to car enthusiast sites - which Petrov joined using variations on "wotan_jugend8989" as his handle. In addition, in 2013 and 2014, Petrov's VKontakte social media account posted Wotanjugend videos, and he shared an announcement about a Wotanjugend festival.

In response to Reuters questions, an administrator for the Wotanjugend online community said he did not know Petrov and it was unlikely Petrov had ever been a member. The administrator said the group promotes a right-wing world view, and many of its followers back Ukraine in its war with Russia because they want to overthrow the Russian state.

Petrov's Instagram account had the handle "fanat1k8814." The numbers 88 are commonly used by neo-Nazis because "H" - for "Heil" and "Hitler" - is the eighth letter in the alphabet. The number 14 is associated in far-right circles with "the Fourteen Words," a slogan originated by David Lane, a member of US white supremacist group The Order, according to US-based anti-extremism campaign group the Anti-Defamation League. The slogan relates to protecting the purity of the white race.

Petrov in 2013 posted this comment on his VKontakte account: "The Roman salute, from the heart to the sun." The phrase has been used among neo-Nazis to describe a Nazi-style salute.

Petrov also posted on his VKontakte account on Sept 16, 2012 a picture showing a T-shirt with a variation of the Celtic cross. The symbol is associated with neo-Nazis, according to the Fare Network, a civil society group that monitors extremism in soccer. The same picture shows a baseball cap with the numbers "88" printed on the front.

Petrov unsubscribed from more than 150 VKontakte groups after Reuters submitted its questions, according to a publicly-available list on his account of the groups to which he is subscribed. One, called "Stay White," describes itself as a group for Slavs who want to revive "Great Russia."

Lebanon's culture minister moved to ban the film "Barbie" from cinemas on Wednesday, saying it "promotes homosexuality" and contradicts religious values.

Minister Mohammad Mortada is backed by powerful Shi'ite armed group Hezbollah, whose head Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah has ramped up his rhetoric against the LGBT community, referring in a recent speech to Islamic texts that call for punishing offenders with death.

Mortada's decision said the film was found to "promote homosexuality and sexual transformation" and "contradicts values of faith and morality" by diminishing the importance of the family unit.

Based on Mortada's move, Interior Minister Bassam Mawlawi in turn asked General Security's censorship committee, which falls under the interior ministry and is traditionally responsible for censorship decisions, to review the film and give its recommendation.

Lebanon was the first Arab country to hold a gay pride week in 2017 and has generally been seen as a safe haven for the LGBT community in the broadly conservative Middle East.

But the issue has come into sharper focus recently, sparking tensions. Mawlawi last year took a decision to ban events "promoting sexual perversion" in Lebanon, understood to refer to LGBT-friendly gatherings.

In a speech last month, Nasrallah called on Lebanese authorities to take action against materials he deemed to be promoting homosexuality, including by "banning" them.

He said homosexuality posed an "imminent danger" to Lebanon and should be "confronted". In the case of a homosexual act, Nasrallah said in late July, "from the first time, even if he is unmarried, he is killed".

On Tuesday, Lebanon's cabinet urged citizens to "cling" to family values following a meeting with the country's top Christian cleric Patriarch Bechara Boutros al-Rai, although it did not mention the LGBT community specifically.

Ayman Mhanna, executive director at the non-profit civic Samir Kassir Foundation, told Reuters that Mortada's move came amid "a wave of bigotry".

"This is part of a broader campaign that is bringing together Hezbollah, the Christian far right, and other top religious leaders in a focused campaign against LGBT people," Mhanna said.

Starring Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling as Barbie and Ken, the movie sends Mattel Inc's (MAT.O) doll on an adventure into the real world. The film has topped $1 billion in box office ticket sales worldwide since its July 21 debut.

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis on Wednesday suspended a county prosecutor after accusing her of being soft on crime, making her the second elected Democratic law-enforcement official to be removed by the Republican presidential hopeful .

DeSantis issued an executive order suspending Monique Worrell, the lead prosecutor in Orange and Osceola counties, and replacing her with Orange County Judge Andrew Bain, who the governor appointed to the bench in 2020.

"Worrell's practices and policies have too often allowed violent criminals to escape the full consequences of their criminal conduct," DeSantis said in a statement.

Worrell, elected in 2020, was not immediately available for comment. Fair and Just Prosecution, an organization of progressive prosecutors, criticized the move.

"This is a deeply disturbing abuse of power that overrules the will of voters and threatens the separation of powers," the group's executive director, Miriam Krinsky, said in a statement.

Worrell is not the first Florida prosecutor whom DeSantis has dismissed. Last August, he suspended the Democratic state's attorney for Hillsborough County, Andrew Warren, who had pledged that he would not bring criminal cases against people seeking or providing abortions despite legal restrictions that Florida has placed on the procedure.

Warren's lawyer accused DeSantis of targeting dissenting voices, but a federal judge upheld the suspension .

In public opinion polls, DeSantis is running a distant second behind former President Donald Trump in the race for the Republican nomination in the 2024 presidential election.

He replaced his campaign manager on Tuesday in an attempt to reboot his campaign.

DeSantis' office sent a letter in April to Worrell's office demanding that she hand over the criminal and judicial record of a suspect accused of killing three people, including a 9-year-old.

At the time, the governor criticized her office for failing to keep the suspect in jail for previous crimes. Worrell responded by saying she stood behind all decisions regarding the suspect's juvenile and adult dispositions.
